unnormalised: Cardiology, eh? It’s a serious business, all about hearts and arteries and keeping folks ticking. But even the most serious subjects have their lighter side, right? Let's face it, sometimes you feel like your own heart is doing the tango during rush hour in Mumbai.
normalised: Cardiology, eh? It is a serious business, all about hearts and arteries and keeping folks ticking. But even the most serious subjects have their lighter side, right? Let us face it, sometimes you feel like your own heart is doing the tango during rush hour in Mumbai.

unnormalised: Take Dr. Rajesh Kumar, for instance, our resident cardio whiz at AIIMS Delhi. Man’s a legend. He can diagnose a leaky valve from across the room just by listening to your breathing. The only problem? Tends to explain everything with Bollywood analogies. “Your LAD artery, beta, it’s like the climax of Sholay, full of drama!” Try explaining that to your naniji back home. She'll probably ask if Gabbar Singh caused the blockage.

unnormalised: And the equipment! An ECG machine looks like something straight out of a 1970s sci-fi movie. And a stress test? Basically, you're asked to run on a treadmill while wearing a bunch of wires and looking like you’re trying out for the Olympics. The poor patient huffing and puffing, the doc yelling, “Just a little more! Like climbing Mount Everest, ji!” All the while the machine prints out a long strip of paper that looks suspiciously like a grocery bill.

unnormalised: Then there are the medications. Half of them have names longer than a Bollywood movie title. I mean, who can pronounce "Metoprolol Succinate ER 25mg" without sounding like they're gargling marbles? You’d think they’d make it easier, like calling it "Dil-Khush Tablet" or something. Imagine asking the chemist for that! Much easier to remember.

unnormalised: Let's not forget about the diets! The ultimate Indian nightmare: “No fried food, no sweets, no chai with extra sugar, and absolutely no butter chicken.” Basically, enjoy life, but not too much. Instead, gorge on boiled spinach and unseasoned oats. Your tastebuds will thank you later… or maybe not.

unnormalised: And the cost! A simple checkup can sometimes feel like you're paying for a small family vacation to Switzerland. Angioplasty costs Rs. 2,50,000 at least. One starts considering if it's cheaper to just take a break-up seriously, before all this actually happens. Seriously though, take your health insurance seriously, friends. It's good for your pocket and your peace of mind.

unnormalised: So, next time you feel a flutter in your chest, don’t panic. It could just be gas. But maybe, just maybe, get it checked out. And if Dr. Kumar starts talking about your arteries like they’re in a Karan Johar movie, just nod politely and smile. It’s all part of the fun, isn’t it? Or maybe I need to see a cardiologist myself after writing this! The irony.
